awd_titl_txt: Learning Trajectories for Integrating K-5 Computer Science and Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
The STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to advance multidisciplinary integration of computing in STEM teaching and learning through applied research and development across one or more domains. The goal of this project is to define the concepts and skills needed for computer science education. The project integrates the knowledge and skills for computer science with mathematics learning goals. This project presents a unique opportunity to integrate such practices with an existing, well-supported and well-designed elementary mathematics curriculum. This addresses the practical needs of schools and teachers in terms of time constraints. The concepts will be organized into a learning trajectory for K-5 computer science and mathematics that examines areas of overlap such as abstract thinking. This project will synthesize prior work in the field and use assessments of students' work with computational thinking and mathematics activities in targeted concepts to develop a framework for understanding students' learning. The project also includes piloting activities connected to the learning trajectory to integrate mathematics and computational thinking practices and concepts. 

The research plan begins with a literature review to understand the major goals of existing computer science materials and findings from research on teaching and learning in the early elementary grades. The review will identify points of compatibility for mathematics and computer science in elementary settings and build possible learning trajectories with accompanying learning materials. Learning module design includes participation from elementary teachers at the school sites. Selected learning trajectories will then be tested in classrooms with integrated mathematics and computational thinking activities and lessons. Classroom observations, teacher interviews, measures of students' knowledge, and surveys of attitudes about computer science will be used to support the learning trajectory design and analysis.

por.por_cntn:
"Learning Trajectories for Integrating K-5 Computer Science and Mathematics" (NSF award #1542828), also known as Learning Trajectories for Everyday Computing (LTEC), began 9/1/15 and ended 9/30/18. The project developed tools and resources for teaching computer science + mathematics in elementary school. Our work focused on computational thinking, the thinking practices used by computer scientists and others as they work to find computational approaches to problems they want to solve. To better understand computational thinking (CT) practices and how they might be taught in elementary school, we pursued three principal lines of work.

 

First, we (i) reviewed prior research into how elementary and middle school students engage with CT concepts such as problem decomposition, conditional logic, and debugging and (ii) used the information we gathered to create CT learning trajectories, which are educated hypotheses about how students' thinking about these topics might be developed through instruction. During this work, we tried to connect CT to everyday ideas that would be familiar to elementary school students. For example, we connected the idea of decomposing problems to activities such as identifying the parts of a flower. By making connections between CT ideas and students' everyday experiences, we aimed to provide useful starting points for teaching CT in elementary school.

 

Second, we analyzed potential relationships between CT and school mathematics and developed plans for integrating CT instruction with Common Core mathematics instruction. For example, we noted that students apply conditional thinking when they use number lines to solve addition and subtraction problems. To find the difference between 3 and 7, for example, students could start at 3 and count up until they land at 7. These math+CT connections serve two different purposes. First, integrating CT instruction with mathematics instruction leverages students' and teachers' existing knowledge rather than introducing an entirely new, unconnected subject into the elementary curriculum. In this work we were aided greatly by the participation of our partner teachers, who designed and tested integrated math+CT activities in their classrooms. Second, our math+CT integration efforts address a practical need: finding time for  computational thinking in an already full school day. If CT can be integrated with mathematics that is already part of the curriculum, then the extra class time required can be minimized.

 

Third, we began using our prototype learning trajectories and preliminary activities to (i) engage teachers in professional learning and (ii) develop a set of practical activities that can be used in elementary school classrooms.


We are continuing and extending this work in a design and development project that builds on this project, "Learning Trajectories for Everyday Computing: Integrating Computational Thinking in Elementary Mathematics", also known as LTEC-2 (NSF award #1742466). For further information, visit our project website at http://everydaycomputing.org. Drafts of selected activities are available at https://www.canonlab.org/actionfractionslessons.
